events.description: Snap vote called by Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi to secure backing for fiscal policies.
Weekly auction of Japanese 10-year government bonds which showed softer demand.
Upcoming release of Japan's fourth-quarter gross domestic product data.

facts.fact_text: Japan’s 10-year government bond yield fell to approximately 2.22% on Friday.

evidences.evidence_text: Japan’s 10-year government bond yield dropped to around 2.22% on Friday, hitting a three-week low

facts.fact_text: The average yield at the recent 10-year bond auction was 2.249%, compared to 2.095% previously.

evidences.evidence_text: with an average yield of 2.249%, up from 2.095% at the prior sale.

facts.fact_text: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi called a snap election.

evidences.evidence_text: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi called the snap vote to secure backing for increased spending and potential tax cuts

claims.claim_text: The ruling coalition is expected to win the election decisively.

evidences.evidence_text: with her ruling coalition widely expected to win decisively.

claims.claim_text: Japan's GDP is expected to rebound in the fourth quarter.

evidences.evidence_text: expected to rebound following a sharp contraction in the previous quarter.

claims.claim_text: Fiscal funding concerns and revenue loss risks are weighing on the markets.

evidences.evidence_text: Concerns over how the government would fund its ambitious spending plans and offset potential revenue losses weighed on markets

evidence.evidence_text: Japan’s 10-year government bond yield dropped to around 2.22% on Friday, hitting a three-week low as investors prepared for this weekend’s lower house elections.
this week’s 10-year bond auction showed softer demand amid election jitters
Concerns over how the government would fund its ambitious spending plans and offset potential revenue losses weighed on markets, amid uncertainty over Japan’s fiscal outlook.
